captions.text: Welcome to the League of Legends Spotlight, featuring Yasuo, the Unforgiven.
Yasuo: Who says I can't handle my drink?
Yasuo is a melee fighter on the hunt for his Elder's killer.
The only swordsman in his generation to have perfected a legendary wind technique, Yasuo directs the currents themselves to dash through enemy front lines and nullify ranged threats.
With zero-cost abilities and extremely low cooldowns, Yasuo thrives in extended teamfights and relies on his high mobility to engage and shred through his enemies.
Yasuo's passive, Way of the Wanderer, has two components.
The first, Intent, doubles Yasuo's critical strike chance, so building 50% crit on Yasuo means his attacks ALWAYS critically strike.
The second component in Yasuo's passive is Resolve.
Yasuo's resource bar, his flow, is replenished through MOVEMENT.
The faster Yasuo moves, the faster he refills his flow.
If Yasuo takes damage from enemy champions or neutral monsters while his flow bar is full, he converts his flow into a shield for a few seconds.
Yasuo's E - Sweeping Blade – affects several of his other abilities, so let's start there.
Sweeping Blade is a single target dash that damages and marks Yasuo's enemy, signaling that he cannot dash to them again until the mark has dissipated.
Sweeping Blade has a fixed distance, so if he's standing close to his target, he'll dash THROUGH it.
Each successive cast deals increased damage up to a cap, so it's advantageous to dash through several targets at a time to maximize your damage output.
Unlike most dashes, Sweeping Blade can be interrupted by all crowd control effects.
When caught overextending, Yasuo can use Sweeping Blade to dash through enemies towards the safety of his turret.
Next up is Yasuo's Q, Steel Tempest.
After a brief channel, Yasuo thrusts his sword out in the direction of your cursor, damaging all enemy units hit.
Steel Tempest functions as a basic attack, meaning Yasuo can crit with it, and he applies on-hit effects to the closest struck enemy.
If Yasuo casts Steel Tempest three times in a row, his third cast sends out a long-range whirlwind that damages and knocks up all enemies in a line.
In lane, Steel Tempest is Yasuo's bread and butter ability.
With its low cooldown, he can use his Q to last hit and harass as he builds stacks towards his whirlwind.
By casting the ability so frequently, he's able to use the knock-up to land extra attacks on Kha'Zix.
Yasuo can also activate Steel Tempest while dashing with Sweeping Blade.
When used mid-dash, the ability slashes all enemies immediately around him.
If he dashes with Sweeping Blade while hitting his third Q, Yasuo also knocks them into the air.
Wind Wall has a passive and active component.
Passively, it increases the rate at which dashing replenishes Yasuo's flow bar.
Activating the ability instantly sends out a wall in a target direction that blocks all enemy projectiles for a few seconds, including ranged auto-attacks, skillshots and targeted abilities.
The only projectiles that the wall DOESN'T stop are turret attacks.
Still, Wind Wall is an extremely powerful ability with the potential to block tons of damage... when timed and positioned correctly.
Cast Wind Wall behind you while retreating from ranged enemies to ensure a successful disengage.
Yasuo's ultimate is Last Breath, which has an enormous cast range, but can ONLY be used on airborne enemy champions.
Activating Last Breath teleports Yasuo to his target, suspending them in mid-air briefly while he deals physical damage to them.
After landing, Yasuo gains a huge, long-lasting armor penetration buff that affects enemy champion BONUS armor.
There are two important aspects worth pointing out here.
First, Last Breath suspends and strikes ALL airborne enemies in the area near Yasuo's target.
Second, Yasuo can capitalize on ANY knock-up ability with Last Breath, making him synergize extremely well with champions like Janna.
Last Breath is an extremely powerful ability with the potential to turn the momentum of any fight.
Here, Yasuo's able to chain his ult with Malphite's initiation to safeguard Sejuani's retreat.
Let's have a look at a few of Yasuo's ability combos before we get into gameplay.
The first is a simple lane harass combo.
After filling your Flow Bar, lead in with E to dash through the minion line and close the gap with your lane opponent.
Land your Q - before dashing back through the minion wave, using your passive shield to help you win the trade.
Next is an all-in kill combo.
After priming your first Q on minions, use your E to close the gap - and strike again with a mid-dash Q, which guarantees a fully primed whirlwind.
Continuing your pursuit, chain your whirlwind into your ultimate - before casting a final Q thanks to its low cooldown.
This combo is especially effective mid-game to go in on your lane opponent.
Once Yasuo's passive shield has been popped, you have a short window of opportunity to trade with your opponents.
Ranged champions can trigger the shield with relative ease before hitting you with hard hitting spells.
Successful Yasuo players will be decisive and either trade back, or retreat before the shield expires.
When entering a fight, look for opportunities to block off ranged enemies with Wind Wall while you pursue your target.
With Ziggs out of the way, Yasuo tags Amumu with several Q's as he waits for him to pass through the choke point leading back to mid lane.
Once there, Yasuo can easily aim his whirlwind and secure the kill with Last Breath.
The range on Yasuo's whirlwind offers great re-engagement potential.
After roaming bot for a seemingly unsuccessful gank, Yasuo readies his third Q before retreating.
Seeing Jinx head back into lane, he quickly dashes through a minion to line up a long-range whirlwind and re-engage with Last Breath.
By leveling up Steel Tempest and building attack speed, Yasuo's able to stack his Q much faster through the ability's reduced cast time and cooldown.
Once Yasuo's in range to land his first Q, his cast time is so low that he can essentially use the ability while moving, helping him keep up and secure the kill with his whirlwind.
Yasuo gets the most from his ultimate when used early in teamfights.
After successfully repositioning himself among the enemy squishies, Yasuo uses the huge armor penetration buff to significantly boost his damage through the course of the fight.
Steel Tempest is on such a low cooldown that Yasuo can incorporate the ability into his standard attack pattern.
While finishing off Garen, Yasuo uses Sweeping Blade to dodge Orianna's ball before catching her with his second knock up.
Had Yasuo used Wind Wall here to absorb Caitlyn's attacks, he might have survived the fight and earned himself a pentakill.
When building Yasuo, there are a few key stats that are central to his kit and playstyle: Movement Speed, Attack Speed, Critical Strike Chance and Defense.
Critical Strike is doubly effective on Yasuo thanks to his passive, and Movement Speed lets him stick to enemies and refresh his shield more frequently.
This makes Statikk Shiv a great early purchase, especially since Sweeping Blade refreshes the item's charges.
Attack Speed directly affects the cooldown and cast time of Steel Tempest, allowing him to use his whirlwind and combos earlier in fights.
Finally, as attractive as high damage builds are, Yasuo absolutely needs defensive items to survive in the late game.
A Randuin's Omen or Banshee's Veil helps Yasuo stick to his enemies while providing much needed durability.
Thanks for tuning in to the Yasuo Champion Spotlight.
Please subscribe to the Riot Games YouTube channel and leave us your comments just below the video.

Sorry, I love Yasuo too much, I just gotta add more.

Before I just drop my build here, I highly suggest watching RedMercy 
regarding about Yasuo, he's a really rad dude (along with League of 
Legends, of course)

Build, not adjusting to situational items or anything, and not in order

Bloodthirster (Priority: Low - Medium)

Infinity Edge (Priority: Medium - High)

Boots (Priority to upgrade: Low - Medium)

Shiv (Priority: Get this damn item immediately)

XXX (Presumably Trinity Force, for that 100% Crit, trust me, every crit 
counts)

XXX (Presumably Guardian Angel or Banshee's Veil)﻿
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.text:
+Speebodoy Oh, early game laning? Depends really, you kinda have to adjust 
with who you're fighting, some Champions require you to go poke them 
occasionally with the E-Q, some require you to poke them with just the 
tornado (Since getting in close would cause you to lose the trade or get 
killed, example: Trading with Riven with E-Q.), And some you just have to 
ask jungler often to help you kill your opponent or at the very least, deny 
him farm. Some may need you to push lane often, some may need you to stay 
under your tower. All depends really, however, in general, just try to 
focus on last hitting Minions.

comments.text:
+Speebodoy Well. I don't think you can. You may, but you can't. Y'see, I'm 
at the PH Server, lol. So unless you're playing at Garena then I think you 
can't add me. Before IE nerf I used to run the 100% Crit rune build (5% 
Crit chance, becomes 10% from Passive), but now I pretty much run the 
standard AD Marks, Armor Seals, and MR Glyphs (Though you should get MR per 
level Glyphs unless you're playing against AP mid, but you need to get 
Treads still.), and AD Quintessences, since I tend to level up E first (To 
until Level 3 or 4), before putting points in Q, although occasionally I 
will put points in Q, sometimes alternating E and Q, although I think 
Lifesteal Quins can work too, never tried it really.

it was magic damage like before though), a good active for chasing, 
escaping, and burst healing, along with attack speed, and cutlass on Yasuo 
is a rather cool item early game to give sustain. Would depend really, 
though I still prefer Bloodthirster.

comments.author: Lionl

comments.text:
Back on topic, Hydra is really a "Meh" item on Yasuo, From my perspective: 
Your E-Q is essentially your Hydra that's on a 1.33 CD, and even then your 
normal Q can chunk a wave,  it's more of a "INCREASE THAT PUSH MOTHAFUCKA! 
MORE THAN YOU NEED!" item, rather than get immediately, only time I did get 
Hydra was during my beginner days with Yasuo, and few middle days with him, 
before eventually settling on Bloodthirster. 
From LoL wiki perspective: BT has the highest AD out of all, along with 
granting a shield and the highest lifesteal out of all. Hydra has highest 
waveclear out of all (Which you already have), and the second highest AD of 
all. And Ruined King is nifty for the attack speed and the damage against 
high HP opponents, With the lifesteal complementing the attack speed. So 
yeah, with a full build, what sounds like the most useful item out of all 
of them? Considering also the whole "Yasuo's E-Q is his Hydra"

comments.author: Ozi Hard

comments.text:
People saying Yasuo is OP, and people saying that he sucks.... wow. Is he 
OP or not? He's pretty balanced tbh.

The "OP" things about him: Double Crit chance, low cooldowns, annoying as 
hell wall, and deals damage fast.
The solution: Ruin him early game, don't let him get farm, pressure him, 
gang up on him if you have to, Yasuo has many ways of coming back, and 
getting tons of CS is one of them, once he hits Shiv, his farming power 
increases exponentially, when he gets IE, he arguably becomes the best 
farmer in the game, but that takes a while for him to get those items 
considering how much they cost in total, and he's VERY squishy early game, 
his shield isn't really that high enough to save himself from a 3 man gank, 
he may need to burn a flash and he might still even die doing so. His 
damage with Shiv and IE is already high but he's still relatively weak, 
it's like having a Super Minion taking out basic waves, but against your 
Marksman that Super Minion is doing shit against you, think of the Marksman 
as you and your team, the Super Minion as Yasuo, and the Minions as... 
well... Minions, or the prey of Yasuo. The Super Minion is OP against those 
Minions, and is very tanky, but against stronger forces, aka your Marksman, 
he's gone in like a few hits.
For the things that make him "suck": Squishy, people too reliant on his old 
permashield thanks to his dash, the high number of his shield AND his old 
Ult range.
The solution: Be careful, just farm up early game, you don't need to kill 
everyone to get the same amount of gold and XP as last-hitting will, ward 
often, rush your items immediately, stick with your team if you guys can 
coordinate well enough to hunt down people. Your shield isn't high, and 
your defense sucks, but you make up for that with arguably the highest 
farming potential in the ENTIRE game, thanks to your cooldown and how your 
kit works, if you guys were to have a race to reach full build first AND 
within a time limit, you, in theory, will be the first to reach it, 
especially with Shiv, Yasuo is also a somewhat situational pick, He isn't 
weak by himself, but he isn't exactly the best, the thing that makes him so 
strong his is his synergy with his allies, having a Wukong makes both of 
you extra deadly, Wukong ults in, then you follow up, the damage that 
follows is fast, and high. Having a Malphite sets up your ult again, Janna 
can even poke from a range before you decide to go in, Or you can simply 
have a good AoE lineup.
Example: Kalista (Soul bounds with Nami)
Katarina
Nami
Malphite 
Yasuo
Malphite goes in, hopefully getting everyone, Nami follows up with her ult, 
reaching deep into the enemy's backline, where their Marksman should be 
hiding, once he gets knocked up, Yasuo ults onto their Marksman, while 
Kalista throws spears damaging enemy team, while Katarina goes in and 
shreds everyone with her ult, at least those caught by the CC, the catch is 
that this team has to be the one opening, and can't afford to fall behind.

So Yasuo can either be really strong OR real useless depending on 
individual skill, enemy skill, team skill, and team comps.﻿
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.text: +MIR! ^ This
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.text:
+Real Original User Name tl;dr but I've been playing Yasuo while he's free 
this week, and I'd agree that he is quite a balanced champion. I've seen 
some fantastic Yasuo mains, and some absolutely woeful Yasuo beginners... 
He's a champion that rewards players who are smart, quick-thinking, able to 
pick their fights wisely, and zone out then solo enemy squishies while 
dancing around teamfights. If you can do all these things while 
understanding your strengths and weaknesses, you can carry with Yasuo; if 
you can't do that, you will be absolutely useless. Knowledge, experience 
and technique will make you OP, not a champion.

comments.text:
+ye hongzhi Oh I see what you meant, had to read my comment again, lol. It 
isn't necessarily restricted to your Marksman (Super Minion and Minion 
thing), it's practically anything that is stronger that the Super Minion 
(Yasuo), so Marksman, Mage, etc.
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.text:
+ye hongzhi Yasuo IS strong, don't get me wrong, but he isn't OP, he has 
counter play (That and he outright counters Ezreal, everything from Ezreal 
is a projectile and Yasuo can wind wall it, but Yasuo isn't tanky, he's 
extremely squishy), Yasuo is sort of like Aatrox or Sion during passive, 
hard CC him and he's screwed, now I know that's a common "excuse" If you 
want to call it like that but practically Yasuo does have weaknesses, you 
just gotta exploit them, the problem lies in the skill of the Yasuo, if he 
knows his weaknesses he's going to adapt to cover them up, to make sure 
none of you exploit it, (Asides Blind Pick) Have you ever tried Yasuo and 
tried to fight a team full of Hard CC? That's one of the worst things that 
could ever happen (Not all of them need to have Hard CC, enough to disable 
you) Yasuo also has no steroids on him at all,I'm not defending Yasuo from 
being nerfed, but I'm defending him from "OP", He isn't OP, but he is one 
of the strongest Champions in the game right now, if I have to refer to one 
LoL YouTuber (I did in previous comment), I'd go with RedMercy, As in his 
"Top 5 Assassins" video, despite the fact that he loves Zed, Mains Zed, and 
is (At least at what he says) *slightly* biased towards Zed, he wasn't at 
#1, it was still Yasuo. Yasuo takes time to learn, once you do, you're a 
force to be reckoned with. Also found this out the hard way, Yasuo's main 
advantage is his short cooldown. (How I found out: 2014 URF)
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.text:
+r3v4n21 Erm, I wouldn't say private or bot matches, only time I did do bot 
matches and private were for fun 1v1s (Privates) and practicing wall 
dashing (Bots), Hell he's my main now at this point. Still though, Yasuo's 
strength really does come from the fact that he can just CS and at the 
least be something to be concerned about late game, but if he snowballs 
good luck dealing with him if you don't know how to counter him, which is 
why (If Yasuo's opponent is strategic) early game Champs can give him a 
hard time, Pantheon, Garen, etc. Pantheon's the one I hate the most 
fighting against, but most Pantheons I've seen here in PH keeps on pushing 
the damn lane, those who know how to freeze the lane end up getting caught 
by jungler anyway, so yeah, if I find a Pantheon that is both good at 
denying me farm and can ward properly (Actually found one and I got rekt 
really hard), Yasuo can just play safe. Especially since doing Redmercy's 
skill order (3-4 points in E) can give you a high amount of poke and even 
aids in last hitting. Of course never did Ranked to practice Yasuo, that's 
just suicide.
comments.author: Real Original User Name

comments.author: John Henry Mejia

comments.text:
These nerfs on Yasuo are kind of balanced in some ways. I think they did a 
good job nerfing his health and dashes as well as his shield and crit it 
was pretty op on how you could just recharge your shield by dashing around. 
He is now easily more counterable and more easy to harass against due to 
his REALLY low starting health. With these nerfs they also kept some of his 
main team fighting and lane potential alive, meaning he is still a HUGE 
presence in team fights as well as noticable presence in lane. As long as 
he can still hold his ground in lane, Im fine with these nerfs as a Yasuo 
player.﻿
